A large ridge of high pressure aloft set up over the center of the country around August 20th, leading to a week-long heatwave across southern Illinois. High temperatures were primarily only in the low to mid 90s most days, but the main headline was the extreme humidity levels witnessed over the entirety of this event. Portions of the region experienced very heavy rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 inches from July 1st through mid August. This set the stage for record levels of evapotranspiration from the vegetation and crops. Dew points, a measure of humidity levels, were routinely in the upper 70's to lower 80's, with several locations peaking in the mid 80's. Carbondale reached its highest dew point of 82 degrees on the 25th. This caused heat index readings to peak between 105 and 120 degrees each day from August 20th through the 25th. The high humidity levels also led to dense fog formation several nights during this event, which was rather unusual for a prolonged heat wave. The highest hourly heat index readings at Carbondale were 111 on the 20th, 117 on the 21st, 111 on the 22nd, 108 on the 23rd, 110 on the 24th, and 114 on the 25th. Many schools cancelled outdoor activities or moved them indoors, including football practices.

column37: A prolonged stretch of dangerous heat and humidity occurred across the Midwest. Peak afternoon heat indices were near or over 110 degrees each day, and heat indices remained above 80 degrees overnight. The Lawrenceville Airport (KLWV) recorded a maximum heat index of 121 degrees on both August 24 and August 25. The AWOS at the Mount Carmel Airport (KAJG) recorded a maximum heat index of 119 degrees on August 25.
column38: A strong heat dome over the Midwest resulted in a six-day stretch of dangerous heat and humidity, which began on August 20 and continued through August 25. High temperatures were routinely above 90 degrees, while afternoon dewpoints were near 80 degrees, resulting in heat indices exceeding 110 degrees. During the overnight hours, lows only fell into the upper 70s, keeping heat indices in the 80s.

column37: A prolonged stretch of dangerous heat and humidity occurred across the Midwest. Peak afternoon heat indices were near or over 110 degrees each day, and heat indices remained above 80 degrees overnight. The Logan County Airport (KAAA) recorded a maximum heat index of 120 degrees on August 23. Additionally, the National Weather Service in Lincoln recorded a record warm low temperature of 77 degrees on August 24.

High temperatures were routinely above 90 degrees, while afternoon dewpoints were near 80 degrees, resulting in heat indices exceeding 110 degrees. During the overnight hours, lows only fell into the upper 70s, keeping heat indices in the 80s.

column37: A prolonged stretch of dangerous heat and humidity occurred across the Midwest. Peak afternoon heat indices were near or over 110 degrees each day, and heat indices remained above 80 degrees overnight. Peoria International Airport (KPIA) recorded a peak heat index of 121 degrees on Wednesday, August 23, which was the highest ever recorded at the airport. Records date back to 1948. The Peoria Airport also set record warm low temperatures of 77 and 78 degrees on August 23 and August 24, respectively.

High temperatures reached the middle to upper 90s on August 23rd.  Dewpoints were in the upper 70s to lower 80s producing heat index values in the 115 to 120 degree range during the afternoon.  Chicago O'Hare Airport set a new daily record high of 98 degrees on August 23rd and also measured a dewpoint of 80 degrees.  This was only the seventh calendar day since records began that Chicago measured a dewpoint of 80 degrees.  Rockford Airport reached 97 degrees wtih a peak heat index of 116 degrees, neither were new records.||High temperatures ranged from the middle 90s to 100 degrees on August 24th.  Dewpoints were again in the upper 70s to lower 80s producing heat index values in the 115 to 120 degree range during the afternoon. Chicago O'Hare Airport tied their daily record high of 100 degrees.  The highest measured dewpoint was 79 degrees.  The peak heat index value was 120 degrees, which is the highest measured heat index value in Chicago since records began.  Rockford Airport reached 97 degrees wtih a peak heat index of 118 degrees, neither were new records.

Chicago O'Hare Airport set a new daily record high of 98 degrees on August 23rd and also measured a dewpoint of 80 degrees.  This was only the seventh calendar day since records began that Chicago measured a dewpoint of 80 degrees.  Rockford Airport reached 97 degrees wtih a peak heat index of 116 degrees, neither were new records.||High temperatures ranged from the middle 90s to 100 degrees on August 24th.  Dewpoints were again in the upper 70s to lower 80s producing heat index values in the 115 to 120 degree range during the afternoon. Chicago O'Hare Airport tied their daily record high of 100 degrees.  The highest measured dewpoint was 79 degrees.  The peak heat index value was 120 degrees, which is the highest measured heat index value in Chicago since records began.  Rockford Airport reached 97 degrees wtih a peak heat index of 118 degrees, neither were new records.

column37: Thunderstorm winds blew down several trees along County Road 1600E north of Coffeen.
column38: A cold front moved through the region. This combined with plenty of low level moisture and instability generated storms. Some of the storms became severe.

column38: An area of low pressure tracking along a stationary frontal boundary draped along the I-72 corridor triggered clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms from late afternoon of August 25th into the pre-dawn hours of August 26th.  Some of the cells produced wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph, which caused scattered wind damage.

column37: The emergency manager observed a brief landspout tornado two miles south of Marietta.
column38: A weak surface boundary was draped across the region on August 26. Thunderstorms developed and sagged south along the boundary during the early afternoon, and two brief landspout tornadoes were observed in Fulton County. Neither landspout produced any damage, and thus both were rated EF-Unknown.

column37: A brief landspout tornado was observed near County Road 34 and Belville Road in rural Fulton County. No damage was observed, so an intensity rating could not be assigned.

Severe drought conditions developed across northwest Illinois including the Rockford area in early September.  A small area of extreme drought conditions developed near the Illinois and Wisconsin state line.  For the month of September, Rockford Airport measured 2.19 inches of rain which was 1.43 inches below normal.

column37: Numerous viaducts and underpasses were flooded across the southern suburbs of Chicago.  Rainfall amounts included 2.99 inches in Park Forest and 2.90 inches in Peotone.
column38: Scattered thunderstorms moved across parts of northern Illinois during the morning of September 6th producing heavy rain, localized flooding and localized wind damage.

column37: A viaduct was flooded on Ashland Avenue between Hubbard Street and Lake Street with a report of a car under water.
column38: Heavy rain fall across parts of northeast Illinois on September 17th producing flash flooding in parts of Cook County.

column37: Heavy rain caused significant flooding and flash flooding across portions of southeast Cook County.  Hundreds of roads were flooded and numerous cars were stranded in the flood waters.  Some of the worst flooding occurred in and around Calumet City and Dolton where hundreds of houses and buildings were surrounded by flood waters and some streets were littered with abandoned cars.  Water rescues were reported but resulted in no injuries.  Hundreds of basements were flooded in Calumet City and at least 30 basements were flooded in South Holland.  While the highest measured rainfall report was 5.69 inches one mile north northeast of South Holland, radar estimated rainfall showed possibly 8 to 9 inches fell across Calumet City.  Other rainfall reports included 5.04 inches one mile southwest of Harvey; 4.72 inches one mile east southeast of Markham; 4.47 inches one mile southeast of Midlothian; 4.26 inches one mile south of Oak Forest and 4.14 inches in Phoenix.
column38: Heavy rain fall across parts of northeast Illinois on September 17th producing flash flooding in parts of Cook County.

column37: After heavy rain and flash flooding across parts of southeast Cook County on September 17th, flooding continued through the morning of September 18th.
column38: Heavy rain fall across parts of northeast Illinois on September 17th producing flash flooding in parts of Cook County.

column37: Broadcast media reported that trees and power lines were knocked down in and around Marissa, with the most damage occurring on the southeast side of town. No information was given on the details of the trees.
column38: A marginally severe environment characterized by low to mid-60s dewpoints and 1500-2000 J/kg of skinny SBCAPE resulted in scattered, disorganized thunderstorms across portions of eastern Missouri and southern Illinois. One of these thunderstorms produced a microburst, causing isolated severe wind damage in southern Illinois.

column37: Two campers were rolled over and multiple more campers were damaged at the World Shooting Complex north of Sparta as a result of severe microburst winds.

column37: A portion of Route 54 between Mount Pulaski and Chestnut was closed due to water flowing across the road.
column38: A slow-moving upper-level disturbance interacting with a weak area of low pressure brought widespread rain and a few thunderstorms to central Illinois during the early morning of September 22nd.  Due to the slow-moving nature of the showers, rainfall amounts exceeded 3 inches in a swatch from southeastern Logan and northwestern Macon counties northward across DeWitt and McLean counties.  A localized spot in southeastern Logan County near the town of Chestnut picked up more than 9 inches of rain, leading to flash flooding and the closure of a state highway.

column37: Street flooding was reported in the Armour Square, Bridgeport and Douglas neighborhoods of Chicago.
column38: Heavy rain caused localized flooding in parts of Chicago during the morning of September 26th.

column37: State Street at 64th Street was temporarily impassable due to flooding and two stalled cars.
column38: Heavy rain caused localized flooding in parts of Chicago during the morning of September 26th.

column37: A viaduct was flooded with a few stalled cars in the 1500 block of East 47th Street between Lake Park Avenue and Lake Shore Drive.
column38: Heavy rain caused localized flooding in parts of Chicago during the morning of September 26th.

column37: A large tree branch was snapped at a residence.
column38: A nearly stationary frontal boundary draped across central Illinois served as the focusing mechanism for clusters of strong to severe thunderstorms during the evening of September 26th.  The storms grew more numerous and vigorous as the nocturnal low-level jet nosed into the region.  As a result, a few of the cells were able to produce damaging wind gusts of around 60 mph and hail as large as quarters.

Following an abnormally dry August and September, severe drought conditions persisted into October for portions of far north central Illinois. Between October 11th and 14th, four consecutive days of rainfall amounting to 3.77 recorded at the Rockford Airport, 2.71 of which fell on the 13th alone, helped to alleviate the drought.

Drought conditions in the Upper Midwest and Central Plains, with widespread Severe Drought (D2) or worse, resulted in significantly reduced river flow along the Mississippi River during the fall. While local drought conditions were D0 in the 10/3, 10/10, and 10/17 drought monitor updates along the Mississippi River in the NWS Paducah county warning area, and D1 drought only added to far Western Kentucky 10/24, water levels reached a preliminary record low of -6.58 feet at New Madrid, Missouri at 11pm CST October 15th. River levels were at their lowest along the Mississippi River from around October 5th to October 24th. River transportation was significantly hindered due to low water levels, with frequent dredging necessary to keep levels sufficiently deep. Tower Rock became reachable on foot again as it did during last years' low water levels.

column37: A very weak thunderstorm amidst a multicell cluster of showers produced a tornado that caused damage to a double-wide residence, its adjacent garage, and a carport behind the home. The home experienced some roof loss. Several trees on and around the property sustained damage. The tornado was rated an EF-1 with a path length of 0.42 miles, path width of 25 yards, and maximum wind gusts of 110mph.
column38: A marginally severe environment existed in northeast Missouri and west central Illinois ahead of a cold front. Multicellular convection developed in the afternoon, with the majority of cells existing as showers. One shower produced a weak tornado that damaged a home and caused one injury in west central Illinois.

The first freeze of the season brought an end to the growing season. Low temperatures in Southern Illinois were from 21-29 degrees. A cold front plunged into the Deep South, resulting in northwesterly winds bringing in strong cold air advection late in the day on the 30th. An approaching secondary cold front and a 1036 mb high over the Dakotas reinforced the cold air, with widespread hard freeze conditions Halloween morning.

Widespread dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less across far southeastern portions of Southern Illinois for the overnight hours. The dense fog formed in the vicinity of a surface trough of low pressure extending northeast to southwest across Western Kentucky.

Widespread dense freezing fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less in the southernmost portions of Illinois near the Ohio/Mississippi River confluence. Fog development occurred in an area of clear skies and calm winds ahead of a cold frontal passage.

Dry deep soil moisture and slightly below normal precipitation in December, following an extremely dry November, resulted in temporary D2 drought conditions in northern portions of Southern Illinois in December. With the agricultural season over, there was very little impact.
